review.title: Differentially Private Regression for Discrete-Time Survival Analysis
review.abstract: In survival analysis, regression models are used to understand the effects of explanatory variables (e.g., age, sex, weight, etc.) to the survival probability. However, for sensitive survival data such as medical data, there are serious concerns about the privacy of individuals in the data set when medical data is used to fit the regression models. The closest work addressing such privacy concerns is the work on Cox regression which linearly projects the original data to a lower dimensional space. However, the weakness of this approach is that there is no formal privacy guarantee for such projection. In this work, we aim to propose solutions for the regression problem in survival analysis with the protection of differential privacy which is a golden standard of privacy protection in data privacy research. To this end, we extend the Output Perturbation and Objective Perturbation approaches which are originally proposed to protect differential privacy for the Empirical Risk Minimization (ERM) problems. In addition, we also propose a novel sampling approach based on the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method to practically guarantee differential privacy with better accuracy. We show that our proposed approaches achieve good accuracy as compared to the non-private results while guaranteeing differential privacy for individuals in the private data set.

However, for sensitive survival data such as medical data, there are serious concerns about the privacy of individuals in the datasets when medical data is used to understand the regression models. e next work addressing such data protection concerns is work on the Cox regression, which projects the original data line by line into a lower dimensional space. However, the weakness of this approach is that there is no formal data protection guarantee for such a projection. In this work, we aim to propose solutions to the regression problem in survival analysis with the protection of erential privacy, which is a standard of privacy protection we originally proposed in this privacy research.

sections.heading: 2 RELATEDWORK
sections.text: Although it is important to protect the privacy of medical data, the work of Yu et al. (Yu et al. 2008) is, to our knowledge, the only work to protect privacy in the Cox regression. Their work considers the importance in which Cox regression is presented to ACMexico based on a distributed data set across many institutions. ey proposed to project patient data into a lower dimensional space using a linear projection. e The projection is satisfied by an optimization restriction to preserve the good characteristics of the original data. However, their work is not based on a formal definition of privacy such as erential privacy. Our work on discrete-time models for survival analysis is the first to propose a solution to the problem of privacy of discrete-time survival models and also the first to apply erential privacy to survival analysis.

sections.heading: 2.1 Di erential Privacy
sections.text: D erential privacy (Dwork 2009, 2011; Dwork et al. 2014) is basically a promise to the individual in the dataset that his information will not have much to do with the significant published results of the analysis. D erential privacy is used in many applications such as the publication of histograms (Li et al. 2010; Zhang et al. 2014), graph analysis (Borgs et al. 2015; Kasiviswanathan et al. 2013; Lu and Miklau 2014), regression and classification (Bassily et al. 2014; Chaudhuri and Monteleoni 2009; Kifer et al. 2012; Wang et al. 2015), recommendation systems (Machanavajjhala et al. 2011; McSherry and Mironov 2009), etc. Here we give a brief overview of di − erential privacy, interested readers can refer to (Dwork et al. 2014).

sections.text: At this point, we would like to point out that discrete time regression models are a good alternative to the Cox regression model. sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we propose solutions to the problem of the protection of erential privacy for discrete time regression models used in survival analysis. In particular, we extend the error approaches to a generalized form in which the loss function is a sum of logistic loss functions. In addition, we propose a sampling approach to practically protect erential privacy by scanning a scaled posterior distribution using the pSGLD sample algorithm. Although we focus our work on discrete time survival regression, our proposed approaches can also be applied to other problems with similar loss functions. In addition, our proposed approaches can easily be extended to discrete time regression models in which the explanatory variables change over time. For further work, a di erentially private version of Cox regression would be a good complement to our work.
